Going from a marathon to a multi-day stage race is a big step. One not to be taken lightly. Things that you can get away with for a single day won't work over multiple days.
But you are young, you have that on your side. (I no longer do unfortunately)
I haven't done a multi-day stag race yet, but I have survived multiple ultras.

So here is my advice, take it for what it is worth.

1. don't bite of more than you can chew. there are stage races and there are stage races. Choose something easy for the first one. you can always pick a hard one later on.
2. Learn about recovery. It doesn't matter what you can throw down on day one. It matters what you can do after four or five days of long distance running.
3. Lighter is better. Everything you have to carry makes it harder.
4. dry is good. Keep your feet dry. Waterproof socks are really helpful, even if you don't think your fee will get wet. The one splash through a puddle can set you up for failure.
5. your mind will give out long before your body does. When you are ready to quit and you can't go any further, know that your body has at least another three or four more days of hard running in it.
6. Enjoy all of it. Win, lose or draw you will be doing something so out there that most people can't even fathom it. So enjoy all of it, even the bits that hurt. Those painful moments will become the memories you laugh about with your friends in the years to come.
